I adored Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman! and  What Do You Care What Other People Think? Those are actually two of my favorite books. Thus, I really expected to enjoy this book, and just did not enjoy it nearly as much as I expected to, for several reasons. First of all, many of the stories from the books I mentioned above are mentioned in this book, but not elaborated on. Thus you learn things like Feynman has a penchant for cracking safes and playing the bongos, without any of the rich and colorful story to accompany it. This book contains speeches made by Feynman primarily, rather than stories about his antics and character. I must say, reading about Feynman from an admiring friend of his is really different from hearing his speeches from the man himself. The speeches were often insightful, eloquent, and clearly made by an incredible scientist, but to read them end on end in book form is a little boring and redundant. Perhaps read one at a time, with a little spacing, that might make it better. That ends my minor objections to this book. I have two major objections. One is that Feynman is very dismissive and condescending to fields of study he viewed as unscientific, like the emerging field of Psychology. I understand it was in its young days and that the methods were not always rigorous, but Feynman's attitude struck me as one that would alienate someone in that field rather than inspire them to learn more about rigorous scientific practices. My second major objection is that some of the book was so breathtakingly sexist that I thought it was a joke. I'm quoting the most egregious example below in its entirety.  " When I was at Cornell, I was rather fascinated by the student body, which seems to me was a dilute mixture of some sensible people in a big mass of dumb people studying home economics, etc., including lots of girls. I used to sit in the cafeteria with the students and eat and try to overhear their conversations and see if there was one intelligent word coming out. You can imagine my surprise when I discovered a tremendous thing, it seemed to me.I listened to a conversation between two girls, and one was explaining that if you want to make a straight line, you see, you go over a certain number to the right for each row you go up, that is, if you go over each time the same amount you go up a row, you make a straight line. A deep principle of analytic geometry! It went on. I was rather amazed. I didn't realize the female mind was capable of understanding analytic geometry.She went on and said, "Suppose you have another line coming in from the other side and you want to figure out where they are going to intersect." Suppose on one line you go over two to the right for every one you go up, and the other line goes over three to the right for every one it goes up, and they start twenty steps apart, etc.--I was flabbergasted. She figured out where the intersection was! It turned out that one girl was explaining to the other how to knit argyle socks.I, therefore, did learn a lesson: The female mind is capable of understanding analytic geometry. Those people who have for years been insisting (in the face of all obvious evidence to the contrary) that the male and female are equal and capable of rational thought may have something. The difficulty may just be that we have never yet discovered a way to communicate with the female mind. If it is done in the right way, you may be able to get something out of it. " That last portion, "you may be able to get something out of it" was like a slap in the face to me as a female scientist. Given his relentless and admirable pursuit of good scientific principles and rationality it amazed me that his assumption was that the female mind was inherently less capable of grasping mathematical principles, without considering that it might be related to differential cultural expectations and upbringing. Perhaps saddest of all was that this attitude crept in when Feynman describes the different ways he has learned to read stories to his male and female children. Overall, having been such a fan of Feynman for years, I still remain one, but I'm deeply disappointed at the way one of my role models viewed females.

"[...] a question requires doubt. People search for certainty. But there is no certainty. People are terrified - how can you live and not know? It is not odd at all. You only think you know [...] most of your actions are based on incomplete knowledge and you really don't know what it is all about, or what the purpose of the world is [...] It is possible to live and not know."This overlong epigraph illustrates Richard P. Feynman's main thesis presented in The Pleasure of Finding Things Out (1999), a collection of informal writings by the famous physicist, a set that could be called "the best short works of Feynman." It includes his talks, official speeches and lectures, transcripts of TV programs, and even Feynman's "minority report" to the official Challenger disaster report. The Nobel Prize winner, a man universally acclaimed as a true genius, returns to his main thesis several times in this collection. His definition of a scientist is:  "A scientist is never certain. [...] all our statements are approximate statements with different degrees of certainty; [...] when a statement is made, the question is not whether it is true or false but rather how likely it is to be true or false."  The only statements which can be proven true or false are statements of mathematics, which is one of the reasons that mathematics is not a science. I wish Feynman's words were required reading in colleges, perhaps even in high schools.The author offers a sharp and convincing critique of pseudo-science where he uses examples of astrology and parapsychology, and returns to his famous "Cargo Science" case that originated from observations of tribal society's customs acquired after their interaction with technology beyond their grasp. Feynman also lambasts the practices of advertising industry and writes that commercials may constitute "scientifically immoral description of the products." I exclaimed "Yes! How true!" when I read the following fragment:  "[...] we live in an unscientific age in which almost all the buffeting of communications and television words, books, and so on are unscientific."  Feynman is lucky to have not lived long enough to witness the times of total misinformation that now exists thanks to the Internet. He would be horrified!Feynman writes about other important topics as well. The last piece in the set is entitled The Relation of Science and Religion, where the author distinguishes three main aspects of religion: metaphysical, ethical, and inspirational, and argues that there exists an incompatibility between religion and science in the first aspect, and that there may be conflicts in the domain of inspirational aspect. This is a fascinating discussion, and as a true scientist the author emphasizes that he is not completely sure of his statements. On a lighter note we have a long item where Feynman reminisces about his times on the Manhattan Project in Los Alamos. We read about hilarious pranks he pulled: safecracking, sneaking out of the tightly guarded compound, etc. The reader can find an extremely funny (and I mean it literally, "extremely funny") passage where the author is awed by the decision-making prowess of top-level military people: how they are able to decide in just five minutes on momentous issues about which they do not have the faintest idea!Four stars.

This book is a collection of America’s finest and renowned theoretical physicist Richard P. Feynman’s lectures, interviews, talks and notes. It is easily possible to be misled into thinking that the book contains technical details; however it has been written with such grace and nuance so as to reach out to readers from all aspects of the society and not just physicists. A nobel prize winner in Physics, Feynman was extremely passionate about physics. His major contributions were in quantum mechanics and quantum electrodynamics.From a very young age, Feynman was inclined towards science; his father played a major role in shaping him. He always taught Richard to be curious, question the working of everything even if it has been accepted by the world. This curiosity paved the way for him to pursue theoretical physics. In one of the talks in Japan, forty years after the Nagasaki bombing where Feynman was a veteren of the Manhattan project (to be explained later), he talked about the power of gigantic computing machines and the future that beholds extensive use of such machines. Even in the 1980s, Feynman had thought about the benefits and hurdles of such huge computing power, and how it will catalyze Artificial Intelligence.Feynman was a part of the Manhattan project - responsible for creating the atomic bomb. During World War II, America was on the verge of losing. Even though Feynman knew the dangers and morality of creating a bomb, he knew if America doesn’t create one, Germany will (probably already had started creating one). This project was based in Los Alamos, New Mexico. During this project, Feynman got a chance to work with many great minds such as Robert Oppenheimer, John von Neumann and Neils Bohr among the many. During the working of this project, his wife was admitted to a hospital, as she was suffering from tuberculosis. However she died and Feynman had to continue working on the project. He is the only person to see the explosion during the test run without dark glasses. He hid himself behind the windshield of a truck to protect from the UV radiation. He also saw a purple after-image of the explosion. To keep himself amused at Los Alamos, Feynman studied safecracking and pranked his colleagues by opening their safes. He also talks about the contradictions between science and religion and how one cannot justify or exist with the other. He also talks about how people accept everything at face value, mostly because they don’t care about the scientific aspects. If people are presented with religious views, they will agree with the views, as religion doesn’t involve science. He also highlights an important aspect about scientists interacting with other scientists or laymen. Scientists should be careful while explaining certain things to laymen, without too much pride. Also, it is said that if you are able to explain things perfectly to laymen, you have understood the concepts. Another advice given by him is “Never say you will give a talk unless you know clearly what you’re going to talk about and more or less what you’re going to say.”

I have in the past seen videos of Richard Feynman sitting down for some interview, talking about magnets and plants growing out of the air, but this is my first time sitting down to read his words at any length. Feynman is a funny, charismatic, and likable physicist. He has a fun way of describing his life and work, and his enthusiasm for learning and discovery is palpable. This collection of essays and interviews is a great "Best of Feynman" book, and I am glad I came across it and read it.There is some overlap among several of these chapters. I heard about "cargo cult science" and how he felt about helping develop nuclear weapons more than three times each, but the repetition was, in another sense, minimal. One interview may have emphasized cargo cult science while another chapter mentioned it only briefly, so it didn't feel like I was re-reading the same spiels over and over.What is unique in each chapter is fantastic. Reading about his coming to be a part of the Los Alamos research team is a fascinating treat. Hearing about his lock picking wiliness adds a funny layer to Feynman's already quirky personality. Seeing how frank he can be about some things, like his perceived value of social sciences, has given me some food for thought. It was fun to see him predict things in the realms of computer science and biology, and it was even more fun to think about how far we've come in so little time.Yet some of the larger issues Feynman talked about are still undoubtedly with us. The destructive tendencies of some humans, of pseudoscience, of people being cocksure about things they have no business being so certain of -- we still live in that world even with our modern genetics and handheld computers.Now it is time to find more Feynman books!

So many aspects and interesting points! Richard P Feynman's father appears to have been wonderful! Education, by him, was finding out how to find out. He personally had no scientific training or education, but he knew about science and what it was and what learning it was!This book is a collection of stories that Feynman has given or commented on over the years. It's a fascinating collection of knowledge and thoughts. I like the fact that it confirms my belief that science is not about knowledge, and doubt is an essential part of life. The problem with pseudoscience and fundamental religion is that they require certainty and they do not allow for "I don't know" or "I have doubt, but let's see what there is and how reality works". And the "recognition" really doesn't mean anything, the important thing is learning; it's answering questions.And his sequence on "what use is it?" really hit home with me, particularly his thoughts about the age of the universe and faraway stars that really don't affect us. These are things that my husband finds interesting, but I don't understand why he studies them. The answer is" to find out! It's interesting!" I don't agree that it's interesting for the most part, but "to find out" is, as Feynman points out, are perfectly legitimate answer!Some of his stories are well represented in the past (like the "Cargo Cult") but this makes a good compendium.a

The first time I heard about Richard Feynman was on the Big Bang Theory where the guys take his van and end up burning it. This is a collection of his writings, memoirs, lectures, and interviews and they draw a good picture of his life and work.I am now in many minds about the man and his life. He is part of inventing the worst weapon in human history as part of the Manhattan Project and that is not what I would appreciate in a scientist. On the other hand, he acknowledges that he should have re-examined his position on being part of it after Germany was defeated because his reason was that a nuclear bomb would have been worse in the hands of Hitler. He is a good scientist in his understanding and adherence to the scientific methods and the doubts that should be on the mind of every scientist but he is smugly dismissive of everything that is not physics or mathematics and has neither appreciation nor understanding of humanities. He has said several things that sounded and probably are incredibly misogynistic in the book and it shouldn't be good enough to say that he is a product of his time because he is supposed to be a genius and see a little further.In all cases, the book is entertaining and has many little funny anecdotes and tells part of the history of physics and life in the middle of the 20th century, certainly not a wasted time.

An interesting complilation of some of Feynman's writings and talks. His passion for physics, and science in general, comes through. I found it refreshing to hear him be humble about his knowledge. A nobel prize winning physicist, part of the Manhatten Project at age 24, and he's so humble about it all. A true scientist.Although I admit that at times I didn't quite follow some of the physics concepts, I found the entire collection quite interesting. And a lack of physics knowledge does not diminish what you can get out of it. The physics is just part of who he was. The larger messages are about science and continuous learning and questioning. My favorite essays or chapters were 1, 3, 8, 9, and 10. In particular, I enjoyed hearing about his time on the Manhatten Project ion Los Alamos. I work for the DoD, and so to hear him talk about the bureaucracy of the Army, I complete got his frustration. And the whole trying to impose that bureaucracy, particularly the censorship bits, on scientists made me laugh out loud. A delightful collection that provides more insight into an incredible genius. Defintely worth the read or listen.And while the narrator, Sean Runnette, lacked Feynman's distinctive NY-Queens accent, he does a great job.

The first thing that strikes the reader of this collection is its extremely informal style, which is partly due to the fact that it mostly consists of talks and interviews, and partly because of Feynman's self-admitted difficulty with language. You will either find this refreshing, as I did, or annoying;I would advice you to listen to Feynman on youtube for a while, and then keep the memory of his very lively way of speaking as you are reading. There is certainly a charm to this, though, as his disdain for empty words and phrases lets you right into his way of thinking.It is also safe to say that you will not be equally absorbed throughout. There are parts too technical for the non-experts, while in different excerpts you will find that a few stories are repeated. But it is not a long book, and you can always skip through a boring passage if no one is looking.What is beyond dispute is the man's genuine and innocent love of experiment and discovery, and of course how brilliant he was at it. The enthusiasm conveyed through the pages makes for a really effective work of popular science.

Always a pleasure reading Feynman.One of the works in this book, "Computing machines in the future" (1985) discusses the physical limits to computer design, including a discussion of quantum computers--a hot topic today, some 35 years later.Sloppy science, another current (perhaps perennial) topic is also discussed in "Cargo Cult Science", by which Feynman means following all the precepts and forms of science without scientific integrity. Scientific integrity means reporting, for an experiment, "everything that you think might make it invalid-not only what you think is right about it: other causes that could possibly explain your results; and things you've thought of that you've eliminated by some other experiment, and how they worked." That is, a full explanation of experimental "successes" and "failures" to better advance scientific understanding.There's so much Cargo Cult behavior in society today--the belief that saying something, with no real proof or explanation, makes it "true" seems rampant in politics, media, institutions. Anyway, the book is a very good read that is still relevant.

A ok collection of interviews, lectures and thoughts from one of the smartest persons who ever lived. The editors could have done a better job.He was a great scientific mind with a clear understanding of what nature really is. He was funny, intelligent, modest and curious. This book has some good anecdotes, some funny ones, some are just fillers and some are really interesting. They way he talks about his father sometimes makes him even more interesting than Richard Feynman himself. Even though some chapters were not what I expected, it was a pleasure to read this book. To learn about the origins of nanotechnology and the future of computers, his work on Los Alamos with Oppenheimer, when he won the Nobel Prize, when he talks about pseudoscience and religion, about teaching science and even about his lock breaking hobby. He was a man that inspires to investigate, to learn, to find things out.

I have very polarizing feelings about this book. There were some paragraphs on science and technology that I read and reread because I loved his thought processes so much; however, his personal anecdotes were consistently appalling.For example: during the Manhattan Project, he strategically chose his dorm based on its location which was across from his female colleagues' dorm building. He was so pleased with himself for picking a room that could theoretically allow him to spy on the women he worked with while his wife was dying of TB in a near by city. He also threw her items on his dorm floor to make it look like two people were occupying the room so he could get away with being the only scientist without a roommate. Sure, it's clever but it's also inexcusably selfish and shouldn't be something worth admiring.The man was a brilliant and insightful scientist. Had this book kept to science it would deserve 5 stars.

I was torn on how to rate this book. I enjoyed much of it, but Feynman's sexism comes out jarringly in a couple chapters. I enjoyed the following chapters: The Pleasure of Finding Things Out, Los Alamos From Below, and The Value of Science. I liked reading about how he learned to love science from his dad in chapter 8, What is Science?, but I found his one sexist, unnecessary comment about Women's Lib in the chapter disturbing. As a systems engineer, I really enjoyed reading his Minority Report to the Space Shuttle Challenger Inquiry - I realized that much of what he criticized NASA for came down to poor systems engineering. The last chapter, The Relation of Science and Religion, is thought-provoking. Personally, I enjoyed Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman better than this book. Feynman fans will probably like it, or at least most of it.

I had heard that Richard Feynman was brilliant. Quirky. A great teacher. A unique mind. I know now that, in addition to all of those descriptors, he was also extremely funny. I stopped the audio book of The Pleasure of Finding Things Out many times to jot down eloquent turns of phrase and pithy crystallizations of profound ideas, but even more than that I laughed out loud. Feynman’s descriptions of his safe-cracking exploits at Los Alamos while working on the Manhattan Project, his joyful recollections of walking in the woods with his father as a child, and his incredulous tales of exploring various pseudoscientific activities are all filled with the kind of soulful humor that makes you wish you had known the man. His brilliance, quirkiness, teaching ability, and uniqueness are all on display as well in this book, but his humor is what makes it special.

This book is a collection of various lectures, interviews,talks given by Feynman at various junctures. I was reading this book mainly for the two chapters "There's is plenty of Room at the Bottom" and "The Relation of Science and Religion". The former is a envisioning talk on miniaturisation and eventually the field became known as "nanotechnology" way back in 1959. I believe in any course you take on nanotechnology or microscale engineering, this would be the first lecture you encounter.Then comes Science and Religion, I wanted to know Feynman's views on that, as one can see when you read, he talks about the uncertainty in the existence of God, which takes away the concept of absoluteness of God which every religion proposes and reveres which is the root case of many problems which is also my take on God and Religion. It's worth the time reading a genius...!!

This is a science book, yet I found in it some of the best parenting advice I had so far.Feynman admits that he became a scientist at a very early age because of conversations he had with his father during their long nature walks. His father encouraged him to question, experiment and most importantly imagine and visualize. for example when young Richard read that a T-Rex's is 15 feet tall and his head is 6 feet wide, his father asked him, so if there was a T-Rex outside the house, would it be able to come through the window? It's Feynman's early training in visualization that equipped him to become the genius he was. Unfortunately, I don't think many parents train their kids to explore the potential of their visual imagination, so I decided to ask my daughter more what-if questions and help her exercise this important brain muscle.A great book.

Well, well, well - this is some potentially life altering stuff, god dammit! If one can adapt Feynman's general worldveiw, it really could open some doors to your perception of the reality you live in and around. His explanation of science and of its many magnificent potentials is exceptional.All though some of the lectures on nano-tech and quantum electiomechanics are above my head, all of the pieces was a delight to consume, even with a limited understanding of the technicality. The lecture transcript "Los Alamos from below" shook me to the very core. The backdrop and building blocks in this true story is bedazzeling, and likewise the absolutely hilarious presentation from Fenyman. A mixmastering of emotions from laugh out loud to deep thinking. Life on earth would really look different if it wasn't for the brilliant Richard Feynman. Thank you!

I’m in two minds about this one. Firstly, it’s an excellent work as Feynman’s achievements and works are both highly readable as well as entertaining. At the same time, if you, like myself, have read the other works that exist, this one adds very little new and even less which hasn’t aged very much.For example, while I had nothing against going through ‘Los Alamos from Below’ once again, I already knew where I could find this story in other books. Neither did I need the Challenger report again for this also exists in one of the other collections of Fenyman’s works.At the same time, some of the ‘new’ included content was relatively old. It was of slight interest to see whether the predictions of sixty to seventy years ago have been fulfilled, but there were very few new ideas. As such, I will continue to keep on recommending Feynman but at the same time recommend ignoring this volume.
This review was originally posted on my blog.

The foreword to this book ensnared me by some weird chance, written by the student of Feynman, Freeman Dyson. An English physicist who studied under Feynman in America, infected by his personality as well the technical accomplishments his theories made possible.Only a few days before Dyson had died, and the name really stuck out for me thereafter from the foreword. Dyson describes his relationship with Feynman by parallel with Shakespeare and his protege, Ben Johnson. This dynamic comes through in this book of short pieces.If you have a chance watch the video series available, for Feynman's ability to describe the complex phenomena of existence in a simple and concise manner is incredible.There is plenty of technical material but nothing that a lay person couldn't skip over without much issue."Come hear the man who saw the first atomic blast without dark glasses!"

A delightful read - loss of a star because much of the book comprises of transcribed Feynman speeches, which in the moment might have made for fantastic listening but made for difficult-to-follow reading. The lost star would also be attributed to some troubling and very uncharacteristically unscientific mysoginistic opinions Mr. Feynman casually threw around. However, with that said, this was a fascinating view into one of the greatest minds of the 20th century - and as an Engineer very humbling to see the massive gaps in my approach to problem solving and my lack of familiarity with the scientific method. I hope in the very least I take away the kind of curiosity to things unknown to me that Mr. Feynman had with all things in life.

For anyone who has already read "Surely you are joking Mr. Feynman", most of the chapters in this book would feel like you have already read them. Due to the same reason, this book wasn't much appealing to me initially but the chapters at the end of the book really got me hooked. The chapter I liked the most was " What is science? ", in which Richard Feynman explains what is the difference between a globally excepted definition of science and what science actually is. This book also has a whole chapter on how he speculated the "challenger disaster" which might look boring to you if such things are not your poison. At last, this was a really great book though most of it is a part of another book.

It's amazing that the author of many bestsellers never authored any book himself. This book, like "Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman," is also a collection of speeches and interviews that Feynman gave. And while it makes up for an average read, what puts me off is how low-effort it is. There's no common theme between the essays and often they 're overly technical or verbose. I don't blame him. They make up for a great speech for a crowd that has the context, but personally, I found them dull. To be sure, not all essays are like that. I really loved the essay on Cargo Cult Science, but I wish there were more like it.

Great read. 257 pages. The book compiles articles and talks by 1965 Nobel-laureate Richard Fenman. Some familiarity with the philosophy of science and the scientific method helps speed along one's reading, as his discussions aim at fans of those topics – science vs. superstition, proving vs. improving, religious scientists vs. religious non-scientists, authority vs. reason, and on. The title captures the theme.Richard Feynman lived quite the life. He helped created the atomic bomb, received a Nobel prize, worked with many other Nobel-laureates, has been called the "father of nanotechnology," and contributed a report investigating the 1986 Challenger explosion.

Some parts were much more interesting than others, but Feynman's brilliance as a scientist and thinker was consistent throughout. He seems to be one of the best examples of a specialist who was able to avoid the dangers of specialization. I was thoroughly impressed with how much he really understood, and how well he conveyed, the real stuff of science--not just physics, but all science (including science education). But more than his passion for science, which is considerable, it was his humility, humor, and humanity that I was struck by again and again. I would very much like to read some more of his books.

The subtitle of this book is a little bit misleading. I expected a collection of short essays written by Feynman. Instead, the majority of the book contained transcriptions of speeches and interviews. As speech is inherently unstructured, not all transcripts were easy to read. In some excerpts Feynman jumps back and forth between arguments, making it hard to follow his line of reasoning. Nonetheless, the book provided an entertaining insight into Feynman's views on physics and science in general. In this regard the book definitely lives up to its premise. Through numerous anecdotes Feynman explains where is 'pleasure of finding things out' comes from.

Just a bunch of transcriptions of Richard Feynman's lectures and other things. Since he worked on such important projects throughout human history, such as the Manhattan Project, the Challenger Explosion and scientific discoveries in Quantum Physics, it was very interesting to hear his viewpoints. The transcriptions are easy to follow, since he speaks more commonly. His thoughts on religion and science were very interesting to me - his viewpoint that "you can't prove anything" and to question everything is a conclusion I've sort of arrived on my own throughout my life. It's cool to hear someone important arrive to the same conclusion.

This book is a great of example of how much a scientist can share when he happens to be an excellent writer. In this book, Feynman describes how he and his colleagues contributed to one of the most controversial scientific discoveries: the one behind creating the first nuclear bomb. Mostly using a reflective tone, he shares with readers what his career among the most famous physicists of all times thought him about the importance of weighing opportunities and their moral significance in the short and long terms.

There was some heavy (to me) scientific stuff to get through (because, brilliant physicist), but mostly this was very entertaining. There were a couple things I felt uncomfortable with...his work on the Manhattan Project comes to mind, as does his rather sexist attitude. On the other hand, there were fascinating lectures. My favorites were the one on nanotechnology which he gave in 1959 (I can't help but wonder how he'd feel about today's cell phone capabilities!) and the final lecture in the book on the relationship between science and religion.

I love reading Dr. Feynman’s notes. He was a bona fide genius, not just in Physics, but also in life. Having said that, this book offers nothing new if you’ve read Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman!: Adventures of a Curious Character. It offers more technical speeches and articles, which isn’t interesting to laypeople like me.If you’re looking for a more enthralling read, click on the book linked above. Much better and more thoughtful.

This is a collection of transcription of speeches Feynman gave, and therefore contains a lot of repetitive material. It's interesting to hear his perspective on science and pseudoscience. Also, he comes across as a bit on the spectrum, with muted emotional discussion of the sickness and death of his wife, and his experiences as "the only one" who saw the Trinity bomb test with his own eyes.Overall, this volume appears to support a cult of personality of Feynman, rather than presenting useful information about his life or from his lectures.

This book might as well be called How to Not be Stupid. I loved the book because he talks about his work on The Manhattan Project, his investigation into fault of NASA's Challenger disaster, Quantum Physics, and various presentations about things like how religion and science fit together nicely and what hell even is this thing we call science? So all of these complex topics but discussed quite simply. If anybody wants to basically listen to long bedtime stories from one of the most brilliant physicists who ever lived, I highly recommend.

Much of this is either corollary to or repetition of material from "Surely You're Joking, Mr. Feynman!": Adventures of a Curious Character. That said, there are some interesting essays on the nature of Science (including the famous Cargo Cult Science speech), as well as a very genuine, earnest essay on the relationship between Science and Religion.

The Pleasure of Finding Things Out is a sort of grab-bag of Richard Feynman's best remembered lectures, interviews, and articles. Although the book was assembled in 1999, some of the writings are as old as the 60s, so at this point the book is as much about history as it is science. For a lay-reader, it can be a little frustrating to read an article, clearly written by a genius, and not know how much of the content is still true or relevant. Some of the articles come with annotations with follow-up information, but it leaves a lot to be desired. Another factor that dates the book are a few phrases that I found to be pretty sexist - at one point, Feynman is shocked to discover that "the female mind is capable of understanding analytic geometry!" And although this is not a memoir, and only sort of touches on his personal life in places, I was shocked at how cavalier he could be about the death of his wife, who he never even named in any of the articles. But I would hope that you can get a more clear picture of his character from other sources, such as his autobiographies. The real focus of this book is his ideas.And what ideas they are! Although he is always downplaying his skills as a teacher, he has a lot to say about teaching that I think everyone who teaches science, and especially who develops science curriculum, should pay more attention to. He is also invested in explaining to people what science really IS. Not what it does, like give us cars and electricity, but what it IS: the relatively new idea that nothing should be taken on faith, but everything should be confirmed by observation and experiment, completely honestly and without prejudgment. One article especially focuses on when science fails. Feynman was the one scientist who was member of the commission that investigated the Challenger Shuttle disaster, and the report he published was almost suppressed because it showed NASA in such an unflattering light. In this article, Feynman takes care to remind the reader that the first people that scientists have to worry about fooling is themselves. Feynman also is unafraid to take on other establishments that can come into conflict with science. In some ways, these articles can be depressing because so little progress has been made in some of these areas since Feynman wrote about them. It seems like the prevailing view among scientists today is to try to show that science is compatible with religion, but Feynman has a more pragmatic viewpoint. Although he respects the contributions of religion in the fields of art and especially ethics, he sees that the unquestioning faith in God that most religions espoused is not compatible with a scientific worldview. In science, you must always doubt everything, so the scientist who believes in God is really saying, "There is a very high probability that there is God." And until there is a church that acknowledges that world view, science and religion will be very hard to reconcile. Feynman respects religion even as he takes a bold stand on its relation to science, but other fields get a more thorough take down. Feynman has very little that is good to say about anything he calls pseudoscience, which certainly includes ESP and UFOs but also includes lots of sociology and psychology, in his opinion. He accuses much of the social sciences of jumping to conclusions to easily, and claiming to be doing scientific studies when lots of their results aren't reproducible, or worse, no one has even tried to reproduce them. I'm not a scientist, and I'm sure there are psychologists and sociologists today who are doing impeccable science, but I've read enough "studies" in the press that find totally illogical things to know that his claims are not entirely unfounded. So there is a lot that a reader can take away from this book, despite being occasionally outdated and repetitive. I haven't even mentioned yet how amusing Mr. Feynman can be - he was the practical joker of Los Alamos, if you can even imagine such a thing. His way of speaking is also quite unique. This editor left most of his work untouched, even occasional grammatical errors, so the reading is anything but dry. A couple of the more scientific articles left me scratching my head, but the big ideas were always clear and inspirational, even if the details were confusing. All in all, a worthwhile read that inspires the reader to go forth, steadfastly doubting everything in the name of science, and even doubting Mr. Feynman himself when necessary.

It's hard not to be inspired by Richard Feynman; he was a great scientist, an honest person, and he put the truth above all else. He was extremely creative, fun, and an industrious person; clearly always experimenting with himself and the world around him. The most important thing I learned from Feynman, which I think he taught many others as well, is his huge advocacy for teaching as a method to determine if you know what you think you know. He also taught me the great importance of true understanding, and how hard it is to really obtain. For instance, one can use a great many big words and phrases, all with the goal of fooling ourselves and the people around us into thinking we actually know something. We say the reason why our shoes wear down is due to 'friction'. But one could equally say they wear down due to god, due to magical fairies, and so on. It's a substitution of a more scientific sounding word in-place of a more fantastical one but never-the-less does not explain the mechanism. Instead, Feynman suggests we should say our shoes wear down because little bits get stuck to the pavement as we walk. The mechanism is more clear; but of course we still have the word 'stuck' which could be taken and simplified further. So we can see how difficult it becomes; to really explain why this happens one would likely have to really explain the whole nature of the universe.I think it follows from this that no-one really understands anything, not until we understand everything, which is still a great deal away. Feynman's explanation here also reveals a subtle method for building understanding, and identifying the mist of what we do know, and what we do not know. This is, in essence, the method of building mind palaces, which was a popular memory technique in Roman times. The idea is to build a spatial construct of interrelated things in our mind, and we can subsequently keep building on this by using Feynman's method of questioning, where we increasingly identify things we are taking for granted in our mental model of the world. Where the mist lies, where the image is clouded in our mind, there our understanding ends. The other important thing Feynman discussed at length, was the importance of scientific integrity and looking for truth; how to differentiate pseudoscience, from real science; the importance of not fooling yourself. I have fooled myself a great many times as a graduate-student, and my capacity to not do so has been increasing dramatically as I realise the serious cost of running on assumptions without thinking very deeply and carefully about the problem, in the manner Feynman suggests above. Feynman also gave me inspiration to continue my attempts at bringing my current field of research from its state of mindless empiricism to become much more like the vigorous and grounded theoretical physics; mind-first, data second. Thankyou, Mr. Feynman!

These things strike me: 1. Social science is not really science, people could make conflicting statements and not the least feel embarrassed. 2. Feynman confess that he posits no teaching philosophy. Different students learn different ways, instead of using one rigid teaching method that caters to some students all the time, Feynman claims to use different methods so he could catch all students some of the time. He illustrates this point with his experience interacting with his son and daughter: while his son would respond to imaginative stories that Feynman made up, his daughter just prefer stories read from books. 2.1 This example echos another soft story of Feynman. His own father told him not to remember names of things, but to understand things. His father told Richard if you remember the name of a bird, you just know what different people decided to call the bird, but you still do not know what the bird is like, how it behaves, eats, et cetera. This was from a period when Feynman's father would take him to walk during vacation in a summer camp, which is rare since no other father would do it. Other mothers liked it, and begged Faynmen's father to take their sons, but he would not do it because `he has a special relationship with me'. So these mothers made their own husband taking their sons to walk during the summer camp. I found these background stories touching. 3. Not thinking who you are talking to. This book is a collection of short stories, speeches and interviews with Feynman. It jumps from laugh out loud stories of Feynman’s adventures at Los Alamos to his futuristic predictions in nanocomputing, to his philosophical thoughts on the role of science in society. We also get a glimpse at his physics research and the state of the field at his time.I found most of the fragments very interesting and entertaining. The only downside is that there really is no central theme or idea, other than the focus on this great physicist and his way of thinking. This book has inspired me to look into Feynman’s other works. He definitely has a unique way of looking at things and is able to present his deep understanding of many subjects in a simple and coherent manner, often with great humour and entertaining storytelling.

Gosh I give a lot of 5 star reviews, but this really was amazing. The Pleasure of Finding Things Out is a diverse collection of several short works by Richard Feynman. The material was gleaned from the transcripts of lectures, tv programs, panel discussions, interviews and the like and thus the chapters can be read in any order. The appeal of the various topics and formats might vary a bit so don't let one bad apple deter you. I found that Chapter 2 was quite dense but nonetheless believe that it was a worthwhile read. However if it doesn't appeal to you, don't let it to stop you from reading further -- just skip it, the next chapter is a really fun. Chapters 1,4,6,10 and 13 (not in that order) were my favorites but I found something insightful, beautiful, challenging or otherwise valuable in every chapter. I look forward to reading much more Feynman.
